data.title: An abrupt end to May
data.meta_description: THEY MUST STILL be feeling bruised in Smith Square over Michael Howard’s summary removal of Theresa May from the party chairmanship (even with the consolation prize of Transport thrown in). It is not
data.text:
THEY MUST STILL be feeling bruised in Smith Square over Michael Howard’s summary removal of Theresa May from the party chairmanship (even with the consolation prize of Transport thrown in). It is not that all the staff of Central Office will have felt any automatic inclination to rally to her defence. It is simply that the older hands there will have been hard put to it to avoid the sense that, once again, they have been cast in the role of whipping boy.

When things go wrong for the Conservative Party, the tendency is always to blame the hired help. It clearly cannot be the policy that is wrong, so it must the way it is being presented. It is the age-old cry of the
